text:
When the servlet returns for example the status code 403 for the PROPFIND method
and when an error page is configured it, which is served up by another servlet,
then the request is dispatched to that other servlet with the PROPFIND method
instead of GET. If that servlet doesn't support PROPFIND, which is evident, then
a 501 status code is returned instead.

This happens at line 363 of org.apache.catalina.core.StandardHostValve.java.
creator: werner.donne@re.be

text:
Another possibility is that the chosen dispatcher is wrong. The specification
says that the path in the deployment descriptor is a resource in the WAR file,
so an error page can never be handled by a servlet, even if there is one with a
matching mapping.
creator: werner.donne@re.be
werner.donne@re.be
text:
I wasn't clear enough. In fact the error page is an HTML file in the WAR. The
location element in the deployment descriptor is a WAR path which points to it.
As a consequence, the error page is nor a servlet and neither a JSP page, which
is the condition to apply SRV.9.9.1. The fact that there also happens to be
another servlet with a mapping pattern that matches the path of the error page
doesn't change this, but this distinction wasn't clear in my original post.

The error page is still served by a Servlet, Tomcat's DefaultServlet. If you
want this to respond to non-standard methods you'll have to:
a) Specify a Servlet for your error page and implement service()
b) Replace/extend the DefaultServlet

If you need further assistance, the tomcat users list is the place to ask.
creator: markt@apache.org
werner.donne@re.be
text:
SRV.9.9.1 says: "If the location of the error handler is a servlet or a JSP
page:". That is not the same as the configured error page being served by a
servlet. In this case the location of the error handler is an HTML file, which
is neither a servlet nor a JSP page.

The fact that Tomcat uses a default servlet inside is not relevant. That is just
an implementation detail.
